comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Great photo. A friend of mines grandparents lived in the house at the time. I believe the plane was being used to deliver mail to the infantry barracks which was just across the street. Waterford Infantry Barracks

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Paul, that's amazing! Any other info? Anyone hurt?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
47290943@N03
comment._content:
Excellent, Paul, thanks for this! I did check a couple of national papers online, but could find no mention of the incident at all, guess newspapers were pretty busy with the War of Independence, etc. When I get a chance, I'll check something like the Waterford News & Star on microfilm - despatches to follow...

You can just make out "ASPEL" over the door of the premises on the left, so that must be poor Mrs McSweeney's house on the right.

Also, when I get a moment, I'll add this information to the catalogue record of this photo. Information like this from all of you guys/gals is invaluable, so thanks again!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content:
The accident involved a Number 2 Squadron (RAF) Bristol Fighter, serial number H1490.
The crew were Flying Officer Briggs and his observer McKeechan. One broke a leg, the other an arm.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24101413@N03] Looking at the remnants of the plane, they were really lucky!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 68114523@N00
comment._content: Interesting shot. My Great Grandfather George Nash lived at 116 Barrack St, but he'd moved over to Liverpool before this happened.
